With FMD Server you can send commands over the internet, from the server to the app. You can also view the device location on a map or view pictures taken by the device. For self-hosting instructions, see the website.

FMD can use the OpenCelliD service to get an approximate location based on the cell tower that the device is connected to. An internet connection is required for every location query. You also need to create an account at OpenCelliD and get your own API Access Token.
Privacy: keep in mind that OpenCelliD learns your current cell tower and thus your location with every API query.
You can contribute to OpenCelliD by collecting and uploading cell tower information. You need a dedicated app for this. One such app is Tower Collector.

FMD (Find My Device) allows you to remotely locate your device. You can communicate with FMD over SMS, instant messengers, or using FMD Server. Locate your device, make it ring, lock it, or wipe it - all from remote.
You need to update some settings to continue using FMD. Click to open.

This application is supposed to work in the background. To ensure it works even when your device is in standby, you need to turn off battery optimization for this app.
FMD will occasionally send you notifications, for example to warn you that someone is locating your device.

Android pauses apps that are not opened for a few months and removes their permissions. FMD, however, is supposed to work in the background. After setting it up you rarely need to open it. Therefore you need to exempt FMD from being paused, otherwise it may not work in a few months.

This permission can only be granted with Android\'s \"pm grant\" command line tool. You can execute this command manually via the Android Debug Bridge (ADB) using a computer. You can also execute it directly on your device using root or Shizuku.
Send commands to your device over SMS. E.g., text \"fmd help\" to your device. FMD will reply with an SMS.

Only phone numbers that are in the allowlist can send commands. To send commands from a phone number that is not in the allowlist, you have to include the PIN: \"fmd mypin help\". For convenience, so that you don\'t have to re-type the PIN every time, this new phone number is added to a temporary allowlist for the next 10 minutes.
SMS may incur costs for both you and the person texting you. SMS requires your SIM card to be unlocked (e.g., after a reboot).

You can allow FMD to read your notifications to listen for commands. FMD can then reply via Android\'s built-in notification reply feature. This allows you to control FMD using a messaging application of your choice, as long as it posts notifications that can be replied to. E.g., you can send a Signal message \"fmd mypin help\" to your phone.
Controlling FMD via Notification Reply requires the FMD PIN to be set. Every message must contain the correct PIN.

FMD Server provides a web interface to control your device, view its location, and view pictures it sent. You can self-host FMD Server or use the provided instance. Data is stored encrypted on the server, protected by your password.
Anyone who knows your username and password can log in to FMD Server and control your device.
FMD Server requires an internet connection. This can be a mobile network (thus the SIM needs to be unlocked) or WiFi.
Send commands locally from within FMD to your device. This is useful for testing. FMD will reply with a notification.
